contentrichtext.text: {{no references|date= June 2013}} {{Infobox Software | name = Accelerated-X | logo = | screenshot = | caption = | developer = Xi Graphics | status = Discontinued | released = | frequently_updated = no | latest release version = Accelerated-X Summit v2.4 | latest release date = | programming language = | operating system = GNU/Linux<br /> Solaris<br /> AIX | language = | genre = [[Windowing system]] | license = Commercial | website = }} '''Accelerated-X''' was a proprietary port of the [[X Window System]] to Intel x86 machines. As of 2013, its website's domain name has expired and the product appears to be abandoned. ==History== The Accelerated-X server was built on top of the [[X386]] X server that was created by Thomas Roell for X11 Release 5. He founded a company in [[Colorado]] named Xi Graphics which provided support for the software. The [[XFree86]] project was created as a free alternative to what became the Accelerated-X server. ==Features== Accelerated-X server provided an "overlay mode" on several [[graphics card]]s which allowed running ancient, 256 color mode-only Unix alongside more modern applications on [[True Color|truecolor]] 24-bit displays. It provided much better driver support (hardware acceleration, 3D and compatibility, especially on integrated graphics) than XFree86, at a time when the major graphics chipset vendors were not supporting [[GNU/Linux]] officially.
